unnormalised: Okay, so someone asked about the typical amounts people buy veggies and groceries in India, right? It's actually quite varied, depends a lot on the family size, eating habits, and where you live. I'll try to give a rough idea based on my observations and experience.
normalised: Okay, so someone asked about the typical amounts people buy veggies and groceries in India, right? It's actually quite varied, depends a lot on the family size, eating habits, and where you live. I'll try to give a rough idea based on my observations and experience.

unnormalised: For a small family, say 2 adults, weekly vegetable shopping might look something like this: Potatoes - 1 kg, Onions - 1/2 kg, Tomatoes - 250 gm, some leafy greens like Spinach or Methi - 500 gm, plus assorted veggies like Beans, Carrots, or Cauliflower totaling around 750 gm. Of course, prices vary hugely depending on the season and location. Expect to pay anything from ₹300-₹500 per week just for veggies.
normalised: For a small family, say two adults, weekly vegetable shopping might look something like this: Potatoes - one kilogram, Onions - half kilogram, Tomatoes - two hundred and fifty gram, some leafy greens like Spinach or Methi - five hundred gram, plus assorted veggies like Beans, Carrots, or Cauliflower totaling around seven hundred and fifty gram. Of course, prices vary hugely depending on the season and location. Expect to pay anything from rupee three hundred to rupee five hundred per week just for veggies.

unnormalised: Now, if you're talking about groceries, it's even more diverse. Rice - 5 kg per month is pretty standard for many South Indian families. Wheat flour (Atta) – maybe 10 kg, especially in the North. Then you've got dals (lentils). A kg of each type – Toor dal, Moong dal, Masoor dal – is a common amount. Sugar, around 2 kg, oil (sunflower, groundnut, or mustard, depending on region) - 5 ltrs, and tea – 250 gm or 500 gm packs, depending on how much you drink.

unnormalised: Let's talk about milk. A family of 4 might buy 1 ltr of milk per day. Curd (Dahi), usually 500 gm, gets made at home regularly. Bread, maybe a loaf of 400 gm every 2-3 days, depending on how much toast people eat.

unnormalised: For a larger family, say 4 adults and 2 kids, you’d basically double the quantities mentioned above. Veggies would be closer to 2 kg potatoes, 1 kg onions, and so on. unnormalised: Another thing to remember is the size of packaging. You can buy things in really small quantities, like a 50 gm packet of spice, or huge quantities like a 50 kg bag of rice. It really just depends on storage space and budget. Also, many people buy veggies daily, getting just 1/4 kg of tomatoes or 1/4 kg of ladies' finger (bhindi) at a time. This is especially common if they live near a market.

unnormalised: Finally, keep in mind that these are just generalizations. Dietary preferences vary greatly. Some people are vegan, some are vegetarian, and some eat meat every day. The specific items and quantities people buy will depend entirely on their individual needs and tastes. Also, these estimates are just approximate values and don't account for price fluctuations which always occur throughout the year. It's always better to check your usage and plan purchases accordingly.
